{{Multiple issues| {{MEDREF|date=April 2015}} {{primary sources|date=April 2015}} {{third-party|date=April 2015}} }}
The '''empathizing–systemizing''' ('''E–S''') '''theory''' suggests that people may be classified on the basis of their scores along two dimensions: empathizing (E) and systemizing (S). It measures a person's strength of interest in [[empathy]] (the ability to identify and understand the thoughts and feelings of others and to respond to these with appropriate emotions) and a person's strength of interest in [[system]]s (in terms of the drive to analyse or construct them).
According to the originator of the hypothesis, [[Simon Baron-Cohen]], the E-S theory has been tested using the [[Empathy Quotient]] (EQ) and Systemizing Quotient (SQ), developed by him and colleagues, and generates five different 'brain types' depending on the presence or absence of discrepancies between their scores on E or S. E-S profiles show that the profile E>S is more common in females than in males, and the profile S>E is more common in males than in females.<ref name="Baron-Cohen, S. 2005">{{cite journal | last1 = Baron-Cohen | first1 = Simon | last2 = Knickmeyer | first2 = Rebecca C. | last3 = Belmonte | first3 = Matthew K. | title = Sex differences in the brain: implications for explaining autism | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume = 310 | issue = 5749 | pages = 819–823 | publisher = [[American Association for the Advancement of Science|AAAS]] | doi = 10.1126/science.1115455 | pmid = 16272115 | date = 4 November 2005 | url = https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1115455}} [http://docs.autismresearchcentre.com/papers/2005_BC_etal_Science.pdf Pdf.] :''Extracted in'': ::{{cite web | last = Kessel | first = Cathy|url=https://mathedck.wordpress.com/2011/12/15/half-of-women-do-not-have-female-brains-half-of-men-do-not-have-male-brains/|title=Half of Women Do Not Have "Female Brains" (blog) | website = mathedck.wordpress.com | publisher = Mathematics and Education via WordPress | date = 15 November 2011}}</ref> Baron-Cohen and associates say the E-S theory is a better predictor than gender of who chooses STEM subjects ([[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics]]).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Billington | first1 = Jac | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Wheelwright | first3 = Sally | title = Cognitive style predicts entry into physical sciences and humanities: Questionnaire and performance tests of empathy and systemizing | journal = [[Learning and Individual Differences]] | volume = 17 | issue = 3 | pages = 260–268 | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | doi = 10.1016/j.lindif.2007.02.004 | date = 4 November 2005 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.lindif.2007.02.004}} [http://www.somersetcanyons.com/ourpages/auto/2016/3/11/48638152/billington_et_al_2007.pdf Pdf.] </ref> The E-S theory has been extended into the 'Extreme Male Brain' (EMB) theory of [[autism]] and [[Asperger syndrome]], which are associated in the E-S theory with below-average empathy and average or above-average systemizing.<ref name="e-s theory">{{cite journal | last = Baron-Cohen | first = Simon |year=2009 |title=Autism: The Empathizing–Systemizing (E-S) Theory |journal=[[Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences]] |volume=1156 |issue=The Year in Cognitive Neuroscience 2009 |pages=68–80 |publisher= [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] |doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.2009.04467.x |url= https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1749-6632.2009.04467.x |pmid=19338503}}</ref>
Baron-Cohen's studies and theory have been questioned on multiple grounds.<ref name=Nash/><ref name=Andrew/> The overrepresentation of engineers could depend on a socioeconomic status rather than E-S differences,<ref name="Christopher Jarrold, David A. Routh 281–289">{{cite journal | last1 = Jarrold | first1 = Christopher | last2 = Routh | first2 = David A.| title=Is there really a link between engineering and autism? | journal=[[Autism (journal)|Autism]] | volume=2 | issue=3 | pages=281–289 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi=10.1177/1362361398023006 |date=September 1998 | url=https://doi.org/10.1177/1362361398023006}}</ref> and analyses of autism have ''not'' found that autism clustered preferentially around areas rich in IT industry.<ref name="easy to understand article">{{cite journal | last1 = Van Meter | first1 = Karla C. | last2 = et al | title = Geographic distribution of autism in California: a retrospective birth cohort analysis | journal = [[Autism Research]] | volume= 3 | issue= 1 | pages = 19–29 | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | doi = 10.1002/aur.110 | pmc = 4071143 | pmid = 20049980 | date = February 2010 | url=https://doi.org/10.1002/aur.110}} :''Extracted in'' ::{{cite journal | last = Buchen | first = Lizzie | title = Scientists and autism: When geeks meet | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume= 479 | pages = 25–27 | publisher = [[Nature Publishing Group|NPG]] | doi = 10.1038/479025a | date = 2 November 2011 | url=https://doi.org/10.1038/479025a | pmid=22051657}}</ref>
==History==
E-S theory was developed by psychologist [[Simon Baron-Cohen]] as a major reconceptualization of cognitive sex differences in the general population and in an effort to understand why the cognitive difficulties in autism appeared to lie in domains in which he says on average females outperformed males and why cognitive strengths in autism appeared to lie in domains in which on average males outperformed females.<ref name=BaroncohenExtreme>{{cite journal | author=Baron-Cohen, S. | title=The extreme male brain theory of autism | journal=[[Trends in Cognitive Sciences]] |publisher=[[Cell Press]] | year=2002 | pages=248–254 | volume=6 | issue=6 | doi=10.1016/S1364-6613(02)01904-6 | pmid = 12039606 }}</ref> In the first chapter of his 2003 book ''The Essential Difference'', he compares with the bestseller ''[[Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus]]'', written by [[John Gray (U.S. author)|John Gray]] in 1992-3, and states: "the view that men are from Mars and women Venus paints the differences between the two sexes as too extreme. The two sexes are different. but are not ''so'' different that we cannot understand each other."<ref>{{cite book | author=Baron-Cohen, S. | title=The Essential Difference. Male and Female Brains and the Truth about Autism | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N9BgBL0JtgUC | year=2004 | origyear=[https://books.google.com/books?id=J4l9AAAAMAAJ 2003] | page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=N9BgBL0JtgUC&q=%22from+Mars+and+women+Venus+paints+the+differences+between+the+two+sexes+as+too+extreme.+The+two+sexes+are+different.+but+are+not+so+different+that+we+cannot+understand+each+other.4%22 9] | publisher=[[Penguin Books|Penguin UK]] |location=[[City of Westminster]], London |id={{ISBN|0-14190944-7}} |isbn=978-0-141-90944-8 | quote=[https://books.google.com/books?id=wklaj03-rtwC&q=Gray+1993 Pp. 223, 246].}}</ref>
He had previously proposed the [[mind-blindness]] theory in 1985, which argued that children with autism are delayed in their development of a [[theory of mind]], that is, the ability to understand the thoughts and feelings of themselves or others. Baron-Cohen says a strength of this theory lies in its power to explain one of the core features of autism (the social and communication difficulties), but a limitation of the mindblindness theory is that it ignored the other main domain in autism (unusually narrow interests and highly repetitive behaviors, also called 'resistance to change or need for sameness'). To address this, Baron-Cohen put forward the E-S theory.<ref name="e-s theory" /><ref>{{cite journal |author=Baron-Cohen, S. |title=Autism, hypersystemizing, and truth |journal=[[The Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology]] |publisher=[[Experimental Psychology Society]] |volume=61 |issue=1 |pages=64–75 |year=2008 |pmid=18038339 |doi=10.1080/17470210701508749 |url=http://autismresearchcentre.com/docs/papers/2008_BC_JEP_Autism_hypersystemizing_and_truth.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090730185949/http://autismresearchcentre.com/docs/papers/2008_BC_JEP_Autism_hypersystemizing_and_truth.pdf |archivedate=2009-07-30 |df= }}</ref>
Such a distinction can be traced back to [[Robert Vischer]] in 1873,<ref>{{cite book |last=Vischer |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Vischer |date=1873 |title=On the Optical Sense of Form: A Contribution to Aesthetics}} In {{cite book |date=1994 |title=Empathy, Form, and Space. Problems in German Aesthetics, 1873-1893 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6JqGQgAACAAJ |others=Harry Francis Mallgrave and Eleftherios Ikonomou (eds., trans.) | location=[[Santa Monica, California]] |publisher=[[Getty Center for the History of Art and the Humanities]] |pages=89–123 |id={{ISBN|0-89236259-6}} |isbn=978-0-892-36259-2}}</ref> who postulated the as yet undescribed distinction between ''[[verstehen]]'' and ''einfühlung''.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia=[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] |title=Empathy. 1. Historical Introduction |url=https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/empathy/#HisInt |last=Stueber |first=Karsten |date=February 14, 2013 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}}</ref> It has become common to describe normative masculine pedagogical traits in boys and autistic children from this framework where parents and caregivers often mistakenly consider autistic children to be lacking in empathy.{{Clarification needed|date=June 2018}}
==Research==
According to Baron-Cohen, females on average score higher on measures of [[empathy]] and males on average score higher on measures of systemizing. This has been found using the child and adolescent versions of the Empathy Quotient (EQ) and the Systemizing Quotient (SQ), which are completed by parents about their child/adolescent,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Auyeung | first1 = Bonnie | last2 = Wheelwright | first2 = Sally | last3 = Allison | first3 = Carrie | last4 = Atkinson | first4 = Matthew | last5 = Samarawickrema | first5 = Nelum | last6 = Baron-Cohen | first6 = Simon | title = The children's Empathy Quotient and Systemizing Quotient: sex differences in typical development and in autism spectrum conditions | journal = [[Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders]] | volume = 39 | issue = 11 | pages = 1509–1521 | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | doi = 10.1007/s10803-009-0772-x | pmid = 19533317 | date = November 2009 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-009-0772-x}} [http://docs.autismresearchcentre.com/papers/2009_Auyeung_etal_ChildEQSQ_JADD.pdf Pdf.]</ref> and on the self-report version of the EQ and SQ in adults.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baron-Cohen | first1 = Simon | last2 = Wheelwright | first2 = Sally | title = The Empathy Quotient: an investigation of adults with Asperger Syndrome or High Functioning Autism, and normal sex differences | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 34 | issue = 2 | pages = 163–175 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1023/B:JADD.0000022607.19833.00 | date = April 2004 | url = https://doi.org/10.1023/B:JADD.0000022607.19833.00}} [http://docs.autismresearchcentre.com/papers/2004_BCandSW_EQ.pdf Pdf.]</ref>
Baron-Cohen and associates say that similar sex differences on average have been found using performance tests of empathy such as facial emotion recognition tasks<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Golan | first1 = Ofer | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Hill | first3 = Jacqueline | title = The Cambridge Mindreading (CAM) Face-Voice Battery: testing complex emotion recognition in adults with and without Asperger Syndrome | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 36 | issue = 2 | pages = 169–183 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-005-0057-y | pmid = 16477515 | date = February 2006 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-005-0057-y}} [http://docs.autismresearchcentre.com/papers/2006_Golan_etal_AdultCAMbattery.pdf Pdf.]</ref> and on performance tests of systemizing such as measures of mechanical reasoning or 'intuitive physics'.<ref name=LawsonSystemising>{{cite journal | last1 = Lawson | first1 = John | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Wheelwright | first3 = Sally | title = Empathising and systemising in adults with and without Asperger Syndrome | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 34 | issue = 3 | pages = 301–310 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1023/B:JADD.0000029552.42724.1b | pmid = 15264498 | date = June 2004 | url = https://doi.org/10.1023/B:JADD.0000029552.42724.1b}} [https://wiki.inf.ed.ac.uk/pub/ECHOES/RelevantPapers/2004_Lawson_etal_JADD.pdf Pdf.]</ref> He also argues that these sex differences are not only due to socialization.<ref name=Oxford2007/>
==Fetal testosterone==
While experience and socialization contribute to the observed sex differences in empathy and systemizing, Baron-Cohen and colleagues suggest that biology also plays a role. A candidate biological factor influencing E and S is fetal testosterone (FT).<ref name=Prevalent>{{cite journal | last1 = Baron-Cohen | first1 = Simon | last2 = Lombardo | first2 = Michael V. | last3 = Auyeung | first3 = Bonnie | last4 = Ashwin | first4 = Emma | last5 = Chakrabarti | first5 = Bhismadev | last6 = Knickmeyer | first6 = Rebecca | title = Why are Autism Spectrum conditions more prevalent in males? | journal = [[PLOS Biology]] | volume = 9 | issue = 6 | page = e10011081 | publisher = [[PLOS]] | doi = 10.1371/journal.pbio.1001081 | pmid = 21695109 | pmc = 3114757 | date = June 2011 | url = https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1001081}} [http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article/file?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.1001081&type=printable Pdf.]</ref> FT levels are positively correlated with scores on the Systemizing Quotient<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Auyeung | first1 = Bonnie | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Chapman | first3 = Emma | last4 = Knickmeyer | first4 = Rebecca C. | last5 = Taylor | first5 = Kevin | last6 = Hackett | first6 = Gerald | title = Foetal testosterone and the child systemizing quotient | journal = [[European Journal of Endocrinology]] | volume = 155 | issue = s1 | pages = S123–S130 | publisher = [[Bioscientifica]] | doi = 10.1530/eje.1.02260 | date = 1 November 2006 | url = https://doi.org/10.1530/eje.1.02260}} [http://docs.autismresearchcentre.com/papers/2006_Auyeung_fT&SQ.pdf Pdf.]</ref> and are negatively correlated with scores on the Empathy Quotient<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chapman | first1 = Emma | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Auyeung | first3 = Bonnie | last4 = Knickmeyer | first4 = Rebecca C. | last5 = Taylor | first5 = Kevin | last6 = Hackett | first6 = Gerald | title = Foetal testosterone and empathy: evidence from the empathy quotient (EQ) and the "reading the mind in the eyes" test | journal = [[Social Neuroscience]] | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 135–148 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/17470910600992239 | pmid = 18633782 | date = 2006 | url = https://doi.org/10.1080/17470910600992239}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Knickmeyer | first1 = Rebecca C. | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Raggatt | first3 = Peter | last4 = Taylor | first4 = Kevin | last5 = Hackett | first5 = Gerald | title = Fetal testosterone and empathy | journal = [[Hormones and Behavior]] | volume = 49 | issue = 3 | pages = 282–292 | publisher = Elsevier | doi = 10.1016/j.yhbeh.2005.08.010 | pmid = 16226265 | date = March 2006 | url = https://doi.org/10.1016/j.yhbeh.2005.08.010}}</ref> A new field of research has emerged to investigate the role of testosterone levels in autism.<ref name="Krieser, N. 2011">{{cite journal | last1 = Krieser | first1 = Nicole L. | last2 = White | first2 = Susan W. | title = ASD in females: are we overstating the gender difference in diagnosis? | journal = Clinical Child and Family Psychology Review | volume = 17 | issue = 1 | pages = 67–84 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10567-013-0148-9 | pmid = 23836119 | date = March 2014 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10567-013-0148-9}}</ref> Correlational research demonstrated that elevated rates of testosterone were associated with higher rates of autistic traits, lower rates of eye contact, and higher rates of other medical conditions.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ingudomnukul | first1 = Erin | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Wheelwright | first3 = Sally | last4 = Knickmeyer | first4 = Rebecca C. | title = Elevated rates of testosterone-related disorders in women with autism spectrum conditions | journal = [[Hormones and Behavior]] | volume = 51 | issue = 5 | pages = 597–604 | publisher = Elsevier | doi = 10.1016/j.yhbeh.2007.02.001 | pmid = 17462645 | date = May 2007 | url = https://doi.org/10.1016/j.yhbeh.2007.02.001}}</ref> Furthermore, experimental studies showed that altering testosterone levels influences the maze performance in rats, having implications for human studies.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Knickmeyer | first1 = Rebecca C. | last2 = Baron-Cohen | first2 = Simon | last3 = Auyeung | first3 = Bonnie | last4 = Ashwin | first4 = Emma | title = How to test the extreme male brain theory of autism in terms of foetal androgens? | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 38 | issue = 5 | pages = 995–996 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-008-0553-y | pmid = 18327635 | date = May 2008 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-008-0553-y}}</ref> The fetal testosterone theories posit that the level of testosterone in the womb influences the development of sexually dimorphic brain structures, resulting in sex differences and autistic traits in individuals.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Baron-Cohen | first = Simon | title = Testing the extreme male brain (EMB) theory of autism: Let the data speak for themselves | journal = Cognitive Neuropsychiatry | volume = 10 | issue = 1 | pages = 77–81 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/13546800344000336 | date = 2005 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13546800344000336}} [http://docs.autismresearchcentre.com/papers/2005_BC_ReplyToHadynEllis.pdf Pdf.] :See also: ::{{cite journal | last = Ellis | first = Hayden D. | title = Book review: Baron-Cohen, Simon (2003): ''The essential difference: Men, women and the extreme male brain'' | journal = Cognitive Neuropsychiatry | volume = 10 | issue = 1 | pages = 73–75 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/13546800344000273 | date = 2005 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13546800344000273}}</ref>
== Evolutionary explanations for sex differences ==
Baron-Cohen presents several possible [[evolutionary psychology]] explanations for this sex difference. For example, he says that better empathizing may improve care of children, and that better empathy may also improve women's social network which may help in various ways with the caring of children. On the other hand, he says that systemizing may help males become good hunters and increase their social status by improving spatial navigation and the making and use of tools.<ref name=Oxford2007>{{citation | last1 = Baron-Cohen | first1 = Simon | contribution = Chapter 16 The evolution of empathizing and systemizing: assortative mating of two strong systemizers and the cause of autism | editor-last1 = Dunbar | editor-first1 = Robin I. M. | editor-last2 = Barret | editor-first2 = Louise | title = The Oxford handbook of evolutionary psychology | pages = 213–226 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford | year = 2007 | isbn = 9780198568308}}</ref>
== Extreme male brain theory of autism==
Baron-Cohen's work in systemizing-empathizing led him to investigate whether higher levels of fetal [[testosterone]] explain the increased prevalence of autism spectrum disorders among males<ref name=Geeky>{{cite news | last = Baron-Cohen | first = Simon |url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=are-geeky-couples-more-likely-to-have-kids-with-autism |title= Are geeky couples more likely to have kids with autism? |work= [[Scientific American]] |date= 9 November 2012 |accessdate= 28 December 2013}}</ref> in his theory is known as the "extreme male brain" theory of autism. A review of his book ''The Essential Difference''<ref>{{cite book | last = Baron-Cohen | first = Simon | title = The essential difference | publisher = Penguin | location = London | year = 2003 | isbn = 9780713996715}}</ref> published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' in 2003 summarizes his proposals as: "the male brain is programmed to systemize and the female brain to empathize ... Asperger's syndrome represents the extreme male brain".<ref name= Benenson/>
Baron-Cohen and colleagues extended the E-S theory into the extreme male brain theory of autism, which hypothesizes that autism shows an extreme of the typical male profile.<ref name="Baron-Cohen, S. 2005"/> This theory divides people into five groups: *Type E, whose empathy is at a significantly higher level than their systemizing (E>S). *Type S, whose systemizing at a significantly higher level than their empathy (S>E). *Type B (for balanced), whose empathy is at the same level as their systemizing (E=S). *Extreme Type E, whose empathy is above average but whose systemizing is below average (E>>S). *Extreme Type S, whose systemizing is above average but whose empathy is below average (S>>E).
Baron-Cohen says that tests of the E-S model show that twice as many females than males are Type E and twice as many males than females are Type S. 65% of people with autism spectrum conditions are Extreme Type S.<ref name="e-s theory" /> The concept of the Extreme Type E brain has been proposed; however, little research has been conducted on this brain profile.<ref name="Krieser, N. 2011"/>
Apart from the research using EQ and SQ, several other similar tests also have found female and male differences and that people with autism or Asperger syndrome on average score similarly to but more extremely than the average male.<ref name=Cohen2010/> For example, the brain differences model provides a broad overview of sex differences that are represented in individuals with autism, including brain structures and hormone levels.<ref name="Krieser, N. 2011"/>
Some, but not all, studies have found that brain regions that differ in average size between males and females also differ similarly between people who have autism and those who do not have autism.<ref name=Cohen2010>Baron-Cohen, Simon (2010), "[https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-444-53630-3.00011-7 Empathizing, systemizing, and the extreme male brain theory of autism]", {{cite book | editor-last = Savic | editor-first = Ivanka | title = Sex differences in the human brain, their underpinnings and implications | pages = 167–175 | publisher = Elsevier | location = Amsterdam | series = Progress in Brain Research (Volume 186)}} [https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/432f/33d618c6cbd648e67e0e1b5fb5b16a67bea1.pdf Pdf.]</ref>
Baron-Cohen's research on relatives of people with Asperger syndrome and autism found that their fathers and grandfathers are twice as likely to be engineers as the general population.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baron-Cohen | first1 = Simon | last2 = Wheelwright | first2 = Sally | last3 = Stott | first3 = Carol | last4 = Bolton | first4 = Patrick | last5 = Goodyer | first5 = Ian | title = Is there a link between engineering and autism? | journal = [[Autism (journal)|Autism]] | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 101–109 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/1362361397011010 | date = July 1997 | url=https://doi.org/10.1177/1362361397011010}}</ref> Natural science students have more relatives with autism than humanities students. Another similar finding by Baron-Cohen in California has been referred to as the ''Silicon Valley phenomenon'', where a large portion of the population works in technical fields, and he says autism prevalence rates are ten times higher than the average of the US population.<ref name = BC2012>{{cite news | last = Baron-Cohen | first = Simon | title = Autism and the technical mind: live chat with Simon Baron-Cohen, November 9, 10 A.M. EST |url= https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/baron-cohen-autism-and-technical-mind-live-chat/ | volume = 307 | issue = 5 | pages = 72–75 |work= [[Scientific American]] |date= November 2012}}</ref> These data suggest that genetics and the environment play a role in autism prevalence, and children with technically minded parents are therefore more likely to be diagnosed with autism.<ref name = BC2012 />
Baron-Cohen's studies have been questioned. The overrepresentation of engineers could depend on a sampling bias,<ref name="Christopher Jarrold, David A. Routh 281–289"/> and a 2010 analysis of autism diagnoses in California did ''not'' find that autism clustered preferentially around areas rich in IT industry. Instead, it found that clusters tended to occur in areas where parents were older and educated to a higher level than were parents in surrounding areas.<ref name="easy to understand article"/>
Another possibility has been proposed that spins the perspective of the extreme male brain. Social theorists have been investigating the concept that females have protective factors against autism by having a more developed language repertoire and more empathy skills. Female children speak earlier and use language more than their male counterparts, and the lack of this skill translates into many symptoms of autism, offering another explanation for the discrepancy in prevalence.<ref name="Krieser, N. 2011"/>
===Development of brain structures=== The fetal testosterone theory hypothesizes that higher levels of [[testosterone]] in the [[amniotic fluid]] of mothers push brain development towards improved ability to see patterns and analyze complex systems while diminishing communication and empathy, emphasizing "male" traits over "female", or in [[E-S theory]] terminology, emphasizing "systemizing" over "empathizing". This theory states that fetal testosterone influences the development of certain structures in the brain, and that these changes relate to behavioral traits seen in those with autism. Males generally have higher levels of fetal testosterone contributing to their brain developing in that particular way.<ref name="Luders, E. 2014">{{cite journal | last1 = Luders | first1 = Eileen | last2 = Toga | first2 = Arthur W. | last3 = Thompson | first3 = Paul M. | title = Why size matters: Differences in brain volume account for apparent sex differences in callosal anatomy: The sexual dimorphism of the corpus callosum | journal = [[NeuroImage]] | volume = 84 | pages = 820–824 | publisher = Elsevier | doi = 10.1016/j.neuroimage.2013.09.040 | pmid = 24064068 | pmc = 3867125 | date = 1 January 2014 | url = https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2013.09.040}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bruner | first1 = Emiliano | last2 = de la Cuétara | first2 = José Manuel | last3 = Colom | first3 = Roberto | last4 = Martin-Loeches | first4 = Manuel | title = Gender-based differences in the shape of the human corpus callosum are associated with allometric variations | journal = [[Journal of Anatomy]] | volume = 220 | issue = 4 | pages = 417–421 | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-7580.2012.01476.x | pmc = 3375777 | pmid = 22296183 | date = April 2012 | url=https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1469-7580.2012.01476.x}}</ref> The extreme male brain theory (EMB), put forward by Baron-Cohen<ref name="Baron-Cohen, S. 2005"/> suggests that autistic brains show an exaggeration of the features associated with male brains. These are mainly size and connectivity with males generally having a larger brain with more white matter, leading to increased connectivity in each hemisphere.<ref name="Baron-Cohen, S. 2005"/> This is seen in an exaggerated form in the brains of those with ASD. Another feature of male brains is having a smaller corpus callosum in at least some regions leading to decreased inter-hemispheric connectivity.<ref name="Luders, E. 2014"/> This is also seen in those with ASD.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Frazier | first1 = Thomas W. | last2 = Hardan | first2 = Antonio Y. | title = A meta-analysis of the corpus callosum in autism | journal = [[Biological Psychiatry (journal)|Biological Psychiatry]] | volume = 66 | issue = 10 | pages = 935–941 | publisher = Elsevier | doi = 10.1016/j.biopsych.2009.07.022 | pmid = 19748080 | pmc = 2783565 | date = 15 November 2009 | url = https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biopsych.2009.07.022}}</ref> Individuals with ASD were found to have widespread interconnectivity abnormalities in specific brain regions.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Anderson | first1 = Jeffrey S. | last2 = et al | title = Decreased interhemispheric functional connectivity in autism | journal = [[Cerebral Cortex (journal)|Cerebral Cortex]] | volume = 21 | issue = 5 | pages = 1134–1146 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press|Oxford Journals]] | doi = 10.1093/cercor/bhq190 | pmid = 20943668 | pmc = 3077433 | date = May 2011 | url = https://doi.org/10.1093/cercor/bhq190}}</ref> This could explain the different results on empathy tests between men and women<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Teatero | first1 = Missy L. | last2 = Netley | first2 = Charles | title = A critical review of the research on the extreme male brain theory and digit ratio (2D:4D) | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 43 | issue = 11 | pages = 2664–2676 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-013-1819-6 | pmid = 23575643 | date = November 2013 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-013-1819-6}}</ref> as well as the deficiencies in empathy seen in ASD as empathy requires several brain regions to be activated which need information from many different areas of the brain.<ref name="Baron-Cohen, S. 2005"/> A further example of how brain structure can influence ASD is looking at cases where the corpus callosum does not fully develop (agenesis of corpus callosum). It was found that autism is commonly diagnosed in children where the corpus callosum does not fully develop (45% of children with agenesis of the corpus callosum).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baron-Cohen | first1 = Simon | last2 = et al | title = Autism traits in individuals with agenesis of the corpus callosum | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 43 | issue = 5 | pages = 1106–1118 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-012-1653-2 | pmc = 3625480 | date = May 2013 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-012-1653-2 | pmid=23054201}} :See also: ::{{cite journal | last1 = Frazier | first1 = Thomas W. | last2 = Keshavan | first2 = Matcheri S. | last3 = Minshew | first3 = Nancy J. | last4 = Hardan | first4 = Antonio Y. | title = A two-year longitudinal MRI study of the corpus callosum in autism | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 42 | issue = 11 | pages = 2312–2322 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-012-1478-z | pmid = 22350341 | pmc = 4384817 | date = November 2012 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-012-1478-z}}</ref> A further example of brain structures relating to ASD is that children with ASD tend to have a larger amygdala,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Barnea-Goraly | first1 = Naama | last2 = Frazier | first2 = Thomas W. | last3 = Piacenza | first3 = Lucia | last4 = Minshew | first4 = Nancy J. | last5 = Keshavan | first5 = Matcheri S. | last6 = Reiss | first6 = Allan L. | last7 = Hardan | first7 = Antonio Y. | title = A preliminary longitudinal volumetric MRI study of amygdala and hippocampal volumes in autism | journal = [[Progress in Neuro-Psychopharmacology & Biological Psychiatry]] | volume = 48 | pages = 124–128 | publisher = Elsevier | doi = 10.1016/j.pnpbp.2013.09.010 | pmid = 24075822 | date = 3 January 2014 | url = https://doi.org/10.1016/j.pnpbp.2013.09.010}}</ref> this is another example of being an extreme version of the male brain which generally has a larger amygdala.<ref name="Baron-Cohen, S. 2005"/> These brain differences have all been shown to have an influence on social cognition and communication. High levels of fetal testosterone have also been shown to be related to behavior associated with autism, such as eye contact. Studies examining the relationship between prenatal testosterone levels and autistic traits found that high levels correlated with traits such as decreased eye contact.<ref name="Prevalent" /><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Auyeung | first1 = Bonnie | last2 = Ahluwalia | first2 = Jag | last3 = Thomson | first3 = Lynn | last4 = Taylor | first4 = Kevin | last5 = Hackett | first5 = Gerald | last6 = O’Donnell | first6 = Kieran J. | last7 = Baron-Cohen | first7 = Simon | title = Prenatal versus postnatal sex steroid hormone effects on autistic traits in children at 18 to 24 months of age | journal = [[Molecular Autism]] | volume = 3 | page = 17 | publisher = [[BioMed Central]] | doi = 10.1186/2040-2392-3-17 | pmid = 23231861 | pmc = 3554559 | date = December 2012 | url = https://doi.org/10.1186/2040-2392-3-17}}</ref> These were present in both sexes. This suggests that fetal testosterone (fT) is the cause of sex differences in the brain and that there is a link between fT levels and ASD. In general females with autism have a higher rate of medical conditions which are related to high androgen levels and both males and females with autism have higher than average androgen levels.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baron-Cohen | first1 = Simon | last2 = et al | title = Biological sex affects the neurobiology of autism | journal = [[Brain (journal)|Brain: A Journal of Neurology]] | volume = 136 | issue = 9 | pages = 2799–2815 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press|Oxford Journals]] | doi = 10.1093/brain/awt216 | date = 1 September 2013 | url = https://doi.org/10.1093/brain/awt216}}</ref> Males have higher fT levels naturally meaning that there is less of a change required in the hormone levels to reach a point high enough to cause the developmental changes seen in autism. This is a possible cause for the male prevalence seen in autism.
==Imprinted brain theory== {{Main|Imprinted brain theory}} The imprinted brain theory is a somewhat similar although not identical theory. It argues that autism and [[psychosis]] are contrasting disorders on a number of variables. This is argued to be due to imbalanced [[genomic imprinting]]. According to the imprinted brain theory there could be a mismatch and more severe problems when extreme genomic imprinting occurs in the opposite sex, which would explain why female autism (and male psychosis) is often particularly severe, which is a problem for the "extreme male brain" theory which predicts the opposite.<ref name="Nature">{{cite journal | last1 = Badcock | first1 = Christopher | last2 = Crespi | first2 = Bernard | title = Battle of the sexes may set the brain | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume = 454 | issue = 7208 | pages = 1054–1055 | publisher = [[Nature Publishing Group|NPG]] | doi = 10.1038/4541054a | pmid = 18756240 | date = 28 August 2008 | url=https://doi.org/10.1038/479025a}}</ref>
==Cognitive versus affective empathy== {{see also|Empathy#Affective and cognitive}}
Empathy can be subdivided into two major components: * [[cognitive empathy]] (also termed [[Mentalization|'mentalizing']]), the ability to understand another's mental state; * [[affective empathy|affective or emotional empathy]], the ability to emotionally respond to another's mental states. Affective empathy can be subdivided into [[personal distress]] (self-centered feelings of discomfort and anxiety in response to another's suffering) and [[empathic concern]] (sympathy towards others that are suffering).<ref name = response>{{cite journal | last1 = Minio-Paluello | first1 = Ilaria | last2 = Lombardo | first2 = Michael V. | last3 = Chakrabarti | first3 = Bhismadev | last4 = Wheelwright | first4 = Sally | last5 = Baron-Cohen | first5 = Simon | title = Response to Smith's Letter to the Editor "''Emotional Empathy in Autism Spectrum Conditions: Weak, Intact, or Heightened?''" | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume=39 | issue=12 | pages = 1749–1754 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-009-0800-x | date = December 2009 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-009-0800-x}} [http://people.ds.cam.ac.uk/bc249/papers/minio-paluello_2009_jadd.pdf Pdf.] :See also: ::{{cite journal | last = Smith | first = Adam | title = Emotional Empathy in Autism Spectrum Conditions: Weak, Intact, or Heightened? | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume=39 | issue=12 | pages = 1747–1748 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-009-0799-z | date = December 2009 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-009-0799-z}}</ref><ref name = Lamm>{{cite journal | last1 = Lamm | first1 = Claus | last2 = Batson | first2 = C. Daniel | last3 = Decety | first3 = Jean | title = The neural substrate of human empathy: Effects of perspective-taking and cognitive appraisal | journal = [[Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience]] | volume = 19 | issue = 1 | pages = 42–58 | publisher = [[MIT Press]] | doi=10.1162/jocn.2007.19.1.42 | pmid = 17214562 | date = January 2007 | url = https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn.2007.19.1.42}}</ref>
Studies found that individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) self-report lower levels of empathic concern, show less or absent comforting responses toward someone who is suffering, and report equal or higher levels of personal distress compared to controls.<ref name = response/> The combination of reduced empathic concern and increased personal distress may lead to the overall reduction of empathy in ASD.<ref name = response/>
Studies also suggest that individuals with ASD may have impaired theory of mind, involving the ability to understand the perspectives of others.<ref name = Rogers>{{cite journal | last1 = Rogers | first1 = Kimberley | last2 = Dziobek | first2 = Isabel | last3 = Hassenstab | first3 = Jason | last4 = Wolf | first4 = Oliver T. | last5 = Convit | first5 = Antonio | title = Who cares? Revisiting empathy in Asperger syndrome | journal = Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders | volume = 37 | issue = 4 | pages = 709–715 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1007/s10803-006-0197-8 | pmid = 16906462 | date = April 2007 | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-006-0197-8}} [http://www.cog.psy.ruhr-uni-bochum.de/papers/2007/Rogers(2007)_JAutismDevDisord.pdf Pdf.]</ref> The terms ''cognitive empathy'' and ''theory of mind'' are often used synonymously, but due to a lack of studies comparing theory of mind with types of empathy, it is unclear whether these are equivalent.<ref name = Rogers/> Notably, many reports on the empathic deficits of individuals with Asperger syndrome are actually based on impairments in theory of mind.<ref name = Rogers/><ref name = Gillberg>{{cite journal | last = Gillberg | first = Christopher L. | title = The Emanuel Miller Memorial Lecture 1991 – Autism and autistic-like conditions: subclasses among disorders of empathy | journal = [[Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry]] | volume = 33 | issue = 5 | pages = 813–842 | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-7610.1992.tb01959.x | pmid = 1634591 | date = July 1992 | url = https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1469-7610.1992.tb01959.x}}</ref><ref name=Roeyers>{{cite journal | last1 = Roeyers | first1 = Herbert | last2 = Buysse | first2 = Ann | last3 = Ponnet | first3 = Koen | last4 = Pichal | first4 = Bert | title = Advancing advanced mind-reading tests: empathic accuracy in adults with a pervasive developmental disorder | journal = [[Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry]] | volume = 42 | issue = 2 | pages = 271–278 | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | doi = 10.1111/1469-7610.00718 | pmid = 11280423 | date = February 2001 | url = https://doi.org/10.1111/1469-7610.00718}}</ref>
Baron-Cohen argued that psychopathy is associated with intact cognitive empathy but reduced affective empathy while ASD is associated with both reduced cognitive and affective empathy.<ref name="zero degrees">{{cite book |last=Baron-Cohen |first=Simon |title=Zero Degrees of Empathy: A New Theory of Human Cruelty |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5QUPgbxY4C4C |year=2011 |publisher=Penguin UK |location= London |isbn= 9780713997910 |page=}}</ref>
==Criticism== The theory has been criticized on multiple grounds. Columnist at ''[[The Guardian]]'' [[Madeleine Bunting]] has summarized some of these aspects in the 2010 article "The truth about sex difference is that if men are from Mars, so are women".<ref>{{cite news | title=The truth about sex difference is that if men are from Mars, so are women | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/nov/14/women-men-differences-science-stereotypes | author=Bunting, Madeleine | authorlink=Madeleine Bunting | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | location=[[Kings Place]], London | publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] | date=14 November 2010 | accessdate=January 3, 2017}}</ref> Some research in systemizing and empathizing in early life indicates that boys and girls develop in similar ways, casting considerable doubt on the theory of sex differences in these areas.<ref name=Nash>{{cite journal | last1 = Nash | first1 = Alison | last2 = Grossi | first2 = Giordana | author-link2 = Giordana Grossi | title = Picking Barbie™’s brain: inherent sex differences in scientific ability? | journal = Journal of Interdisciplinary Feminist Thought, special issue: Women and Science | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | page = 5 | publisher = Springer | date = 2007 | url = http://digitalcommons.salve.edu/jift/vol2/iss1/5}} [http://digitalcommons.salve.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1016&context=jift Pdf.]</ref> A cognitive style that more naturally opposes empathizing is [[Machiavellianism]], which emphasizes self-interest and which has been shown to be strongly correlated with competitiveness; [[evolutionary theory]] predicts that males will be more competitive than females. In contrast, research has generally shown a weak negative correlation between empathizing and systemizing.<ref name=Andrew/>
Another criticism is that original EQ and SQ, which form most of the research basis behind the notions of empathizing and systemizing, both clearly measure more than one factor, and that sex differences exist on only some of the factors.<ref name=Andrew>{{cite journal | last1 = Andrew | first1 = J. | last2 = Cooke | first2 = M. | last3 = Muncer | first3 = Steven J. | title = The relationship between empathy and Machiavellianism: an alternative to empathizing–systemizing theory | journal = [[Personality and Individual Differences]] | volume = 44 | issue = 5 | pages = 1203–1211 | publisher = Elsevier | doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2007.11.014 | date = April 2008 | url = https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2007.11.014}}</ref>
As a basis for his theory, Baron-Cohen cites a study done on newborn infants in which baby boys looked longer at an object and baby girls looked longer at a person.<ref name="spelke">{{cite journal | last = Spelke | first = Elizabeth S. | title = Sex differences in intrinsic aptitude for mathematics and science?: A critical review | journal = [[American Psychologist]] | volume = 60 | issue = 9 | pages = 950–958 | publisher = [[American Psychological Association]] via [[PsycNET]] | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.60.9.950 | pmid = 16366817 | date = December 2005 | url = https://doi.org/10.1037/0003-066X.60.9.950}} [https://software.rc.fas.harvard.edu/lds/wp-content/uploads/2010/07/spelke2005.pdf Pdf.]</ref> However, a review of studies done with very young children found no consistent differences between boys and girls.<ref name="spelke"/>
Critics say that because his work has focused on higher-functioning individuals with autism spectrum disorders, his work requires independent replication with broader samples.<ref name=Buchen>{{cite journal | last = Buchen | first = Lizzie | title = Scientists and autism: When geeks meet | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume= 479 | pages = 25–27 | publisher = [[Nature Publishing Group|NPG]] | doi = 10.1038/479025a | pmid = 22051657 | date = 2 November 2011 | url=https://doi.org/10.1038/479025a}}</ref> A ''Nature'' article published in 2011 says, "Some critics are also rankled by Baron-Cohen's history of headline-grabbing theories—particularly one that autism is an 'extreme male' brain state. They worry that his theory about technically minded parents may be giving the public wrong ideas, including the impression that autism is linked to being a 'geek'."<ref name=Buchen/>
''Time'' magazine said Baron-Cohen "most dramatically wandered into fraught territory in 2003, when he published the book ''The Essential Difference'', which called autism a manifestation of an extreme 'male brain'--one that's 'predominantly hard-wired for understanding and building systems,' as opposed to a 'female brain,' one that's 'predominantly hard-wired for empathy'--and ended up on the wrong side of the debate on science and sex differences."<ref name=Time>{{cite news | last = Warner | first = Judith |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2089358,00.html |title= Autism's lone wolf |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date= 29 August 2011 |accessdate= 28 December 2013}}</ref> A book review published in the journal ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', wrote:<blockquote> "The idea that males are more interested in systemizing than females merits serious consideration ... It is unquestionably a novel and fascinating idea that seems likely to generate a rich empirical body of literature as its properties are tested. The second part of the theory—that females are more empathic than males—is more problematic."<ref name=Benenson>{{cite journal | last = Benenson | first = Joyce F. | title = Sex on the brain | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume= 424 | issue = 6945 | pages = 132–133 | publisher = [[Nature Publishing Group|NPG]] | doi = 10.1038/424132b | date = 10 July 2003 | url=https://doi.org/10.1038/424132b}}</ref></blockquote>
Colleagues [[Isabelle Rapin]] and [[Helen Tager-Flusberg]] expressed reservations about the theory;<ref name=McGough/> <blockquote>Isabelle Rapin ... finds Dr. Baron-Cohen's theory "provocative" but adds that "it does not account for some of the many neurological features of the disorder, like the motor symptoms [such as repetitive movements and clumsiness], the sleep problems or the seizures." Others worry that the term "extreme male brain" could be misinterpreted. Males are commonly associated with "qualities such as aggression," says Helen Tager-Flusberg ... "What's dangerous is that's the inference people will make: Oh, these are extreme males."<ref name=McGough>{{cite news | last = McGough | first = Robert |title= Is the autistic brain too masculine? | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10583036864206600 |work= Wall Street Journal |date= 16 July 2003 |page= B1}}</ref></blockquote>
''Phenomenology and the Cognitive Sciences'' characterized ''The Essential Difference'' as "very disappointing" with a "superficial notion of intelligence", concluding that Baron-Cohen's major claims about mind-blindness and systemizing–empathizing are "at best, dubious".<ref name= Levy>{{cite journal | last = Levy | first = Neil | title = Book review: Understanding blindness | journal = Phenomenology and the Cognitive Sciences | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 315–324 | publisher = Springer | doi = 10.1023/B:PHEN.0000049328.20506.a1 | date = September 2004 | url = https://doi.org/10.1023/B:PHEN.0000049328.20506.a1}}</ref> ''[[The Spectator]]'' says that "The emphasis on the ultra-maleness approach is no doubt attributable to the fact that Baron-Cohen works mainly with higher functioning autism and Asperger's syndrome."<ref>{{cite news | last = Lawson-Tancred | first = Hugh |url= http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/14th-june-2003/67/what-little-boys-and-girls-are-made-of |title= What little boys and girls are made of | work = [[The Spectator]] |date= 14 June 2003 |page= 67 |accessdate= 29 December 2013}}</ref>
In her 2010 book ''[[Delusions of Gender]]'', [[Cordelia Fine]] used Baron-Cohen's views as an example of "[[neurosexism]]"; she also criticized some of the experimental work that Baron-Cohen claims supports his views as being methodologically flawed.<ref>{{cite book | last = Fine | first =Cordelia | authorlink=Cordelia Fine | title=Delusions of Gender. How Our Minds, Society, and Neurosexism Create Difference'' | url=https://books.google.com/?id=s2ZtdAx83yMC&printsec=frontcover | date=30 August 2010 | publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]] | location=New York City| id={{ISBN|0-39307925-2}} | ISBN=978-0-393-07925-8 | quote=[https://books.google.com/?id=s2ZtdAx83yMC&q=%22Baron-Cohen%22#v=snippet Quotes].}}</ref><ref name="Halpern2010">{{cite journal | last1 = Halpern | first1 = Diane F. | title = How neuromythologies support sex role stereotypes | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume = 330 | issue = 6009 | pages = 1320–1321 | publisher = [[American Association for the Advancement of Science|AAAS]] | doi = 10.1126/science.1198057 | date = 3 December 2010 | url = https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1198057}}</ref> He replied to her critique in ''The Guardian''<ref>{{Cite news | last=Baron-Cohen | first = Simon | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/may/03/biology-sexist-gender-stereotypes | title=It's not sexist to accept that biology affects behaviour | date=3 May 2010 | work = The Guardian | accessdate=3 January 2017}}</ref> and in ''[[The Psychologist (publication)|The Psychologist]]'' publication.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Baron-Cohen | first = Simon | title = Book review: ''Delusions of Gender'' – ‘neurosexism’, biology and politics | journal = [[The Psychologist (magazine)|The Psychologist]] | volume = 23 | issue = 11 | pages = 904–905 | publisher = [[British Psychological Society]] | date = November 2010 | url = http://thepsychologist.bps.org.uk/volume-23/edition-11/book-reviews}} :See also Fine's response: ::{{cite journal | last = Fine | first = Cordelia | title = Forum: Seductive arguments? | journal = The Psychologist | volume = 23 | issue = 12 | pages = 948–949 | date = December 2010 | url = https://thepsychologist.bps.org.uk/volume-23/edition-12/forum}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110708192356/http://www.cordeliafine.com/Fine_Response_Psychologist_December_2010.pdf Pdf.]</ref>
In her 2017 book ''[[Inferior: How Science Got Women Wrong and the New Research That’s Rewriting the Story]]'', [[Angela Saini]] has relaunched the critique that the studies from Baron-Cohen and his colleagues carry on [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]]'s "idea that man and woman...evolved to meet their roles of hunter and gatherer, respectively."<ref>{{cite news |last=Vaswani |first=Anjana |title=Fighting Science with Science |url=http://ahmedabadmirror.indiatimes.com/entertainment/unwind/fighting-science-with-science/articleshow/59974118.cms |newspaper=[[Ahmedabad Mirror]] |date=9 August 2017 |accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Saini |first=Angela |authorlink=Angela Saini |title=[[Inferior: How Science Got Women Wrong and the New Research That’s Rewriting the Story]] |year=2017 |chapter=Chapter 1. Woman's Inferiority to Man (pp. 13—28) |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/?id=U5DEDgAAQBAJ&pg=PP9&dq=%22Chapter+1%22%22Woman%27s+Inferiority+to+Man+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+.+13%22 |publisher=[[Beacon Press]] |location=[[Boston]] |isbn=0-8070-7170-6 |quote=[https://books.google.com/?id=U5DEDgAAQBAJ&q=Darwin Darwin.]}}</ref><ref>Before even "Baron-Cohen and his colleagues", already the neo-[[Kantism|Kantian]] [[Lawrence Kohlberg]] (1927 – 1987) with his "[[Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development|stages of moral development]]", [[Carol Gilligan]] (b. 1936) with her ''[[Ethics of care#Carol Gilligan and In a Different Voice|In a Different Voice]]'' (1982), and [[Nancy Chodorow]] (b. 1944) were followers of such an aspect of Darwinian evolutionary theory. But their generation of gender diversity scholars tried to judge differences as parithetic and complementary values, not as conflicting and hierarchical ones.</ref>

In [[:Category theory]] and related fields of mathematics, an '''envelope''' is a construction that generalizes the operations of "exterior completion", like completion of a locally convex space, or [[Stone–Čech compactification]] of a topological space. A dual construction is called [[Refinement (category theory)|refinement]].
== Definition ==
Suppose <math>K</math> is a category, <math>X</math> an object in <math>K</math>, and <math>\Omega</math> and <math>\Phi</math> two classes of morphisms in <math>K</math>. The definition{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=42}} of an envelope of <math>X</math> in the class <math>\Omega</math> with respect to the class <math>\Phi</math> consists of two steps. [[File:Extension-3.jpg|thumb|Extension.]]
* A morphism <math>\sigma:X\to X'</math> in <math>K</math> is called an ''extension of the object <math>X</math> in the class of morphisms <math>\Omega</math> with respect to the class of morphisms <math>\Phi</math>'', if <math>\sigma\in\Omega</math>, and for any morphism <math>\varphi:X\to B</math> from the class <math>\Phi</math> there exists a unique morphism <math>\varphi':X'\to B</math> in <math>K</math> such that <math>\varphi=\varphi'\circ\sigma</math>. [[File:Envelope-3.jpg|thumb|Envelope.]]
* An extension <math>\rho:X\to E</math> of the object <math>X</math> in the class of morphisms <math>\Omega</math> with respect to the class of morphisms <math>\Phi</math> is called an ''envelope of <math>X</math> in <math>\Omega</math> with respect to <math>\Phi</math>'', if for any other extension <math>\sigma:X\to X'</math> (of <math>X</math> in <math>\Omega</math> with respect to <math>\Phi</math>) there is a unique morphism <math>\upsilon:X'\to E</math> in <math>K</math> such that <math>\rho=\upsilon\circ\sigma</math>. The object <math>E</math> is also called an ''envelope of <math>X</math> in <math>\Omega</math> with respect to <math>\Phi</math>''.
Notations:
<math> \rho=\text{env}_{\Phi}^{\Omega}X, \qquad E=\text{Env}_{\Phi}^{\Omega}X. </math>
In a special case when <math>\Omega</math> is a class of all morphisms whose ranges belong to a given class of objects <math>L</math> in <math>K</math> it is convenient to replace <math>\Omega</math> with <math>L</math> in the notations (and in the terms):
<math> \rho=\text{env}_{\Phi}^L X, \qquad E=\text{Env}_{\Phi}^L X. </math>
Similarly, if <math>\Phi</math> is a class of all morphisms whose ranges belong to a given class of objects <math>M</math> in <math>K</math> it is convenient to replace <math>\Phi</math> with <math>M</math> in the notations (and in the terms):
<math> \rho=\text{env}_M^{\Omega} X, \qquad E=\text{Env}_M^{\Omega} X. </math>
For example, one can speak about an ''envelope of <math>X</math> in the class of objects <math>L</math> with respect to the class of objects <math>M</math>'':
<math> \rho=\text{env}_M^L X, \qquad E=\text{Env}_M^L X. </math>
== Examples ==
# The ''completion'' <math>X^\blacktriangledown</math> of a [[locally convex topological vector space]] <math>X</math> is an envelope of <math>X</math> in the category <math>\text{LCS}</math> of all locally convex spaces with respect to the class <math>\text{Ban}</math> of [[Banach space]]s:{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=50}} <math> X^\blacktriangledown=\text{Env}_{\text{Ban}}^{\text{LCS}}X.</math> # The [[Stone–Čech compactification]] <math>\beta:X\to\beta X</math> of a Tikhonov [[topological space]] <math>X</math> is an envelope of <math>X</math> in the category <math>\text{Tikh}</math> of all Tikhonov spaces in the class <math>\text{Com}</math> of [[compact space]]s with respect to the same class <math>\text{Com}</math>:{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=50}} <math> \beta X=\text{Env}_{\text{Com}}^{\text{Com}}X. </math> # The ''Arens-Michael envelope''{{sfn|Helemskii|1993|p=264}}{{sfn|Pirkovskii|2008}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2009|p=542}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2010|p=275}} <math>A^{\text{AM}}</math> of a locally convex topological algebra <math>A</math> with a separately continuous multiplication is an envelope of <math>A</math> in the category <math>\text{TopAlg}</math> of all (locally convex) topological algebras (with separately continuous multiplications) in the class <math>\text{TopAlg}</math> with respect to the class <math>\text{Ban}</math> of Banach algebras: <math> A^{\text{AM}}= \text{Env}_{\text{Ban}}^{\text{TopAlg}}A. </math> # The ''holomorphic envelope''{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=170}} <math>\text{Env}_{\cal O} A</math> of a [[stereotype algebra]] <math>A</math> is an envelope of <math>A</math> in the category <math>\text{SteAlg}</math> of all stereotype algebras in the class <math>\text{DEpi}</math> of all ''dense'' epimorphisms<ref name=DEpi>A morphism (i.e. a continuous unital homomorphism) of stereotype algebras <math>\varphi:A\to B</math> is called dense if its set of values <math>\varphi(A)</math> is dense in <math>B</math>. </ref> in <math>\text{SteAlg}</math> with respect to the class <math>\text{Ban}</math> of all Banach algebras: <math> \text{Env}_{\cal O} A= \text{Env}_{\text{Ban}}^{\text{DEpi}}A. </math> # The ''smooth envelope''{{sfn|Akbarov|2017|issue=6|p=741}} <math>\text{Env}_{\cal E} A</math> of a [[stereotype algebra]] <math>A</math> is an envelope of <math>A</math> in the category <math>\text{InvSteAlg}</math> of all involutive stereotype algebras in the class <math>\text{DEpi}</math> of all ''dense'' epimorphisms<ref name=DEpi /> in <math>\text{InvSteAlg}</math> with respect to the class <math>\text{DiffMor}</math> of all differential homomorphisms into various C*-algebras with joined self-adjoined nilpotent elements: <math>\text{Env}_{\cal E} A= \text{Env}_{\text{DiffMor}}^{\text{DEpi}}A. </math> # The ''continuous envelope''{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=179}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017|issue=6|p=673}} <math>\text{Env}_{\cal C} A</math> of a [[stereotype algebra]] <math>A</math> is an envelope of <math>A</math> in the category <math>\text{InvSteAlg}</math> of all involutive stereotype algebras in the class <math>\text{DEpi}</math> of all ''dense'' epimorphisms<ref name=DEpi /> in <math>\text{InvSteAlg}</math> with respect to the class <math>\text{C}^*</math> of all C*-algebras: <math>\text{Env}_{\cal C} A= \text{Env}_{\text{C}^*}^{\text{DEpi}}A. </math>
== Applications ==
Envelopes appear as standard functors in various fields of mathematics. Apart from the examples given above,
* the [[Gelfand transform]] <math> G_A:A\to C(\text{Spec} A)</math> of a commutative involutive [[stereotype algebra]] <math>A</math> is a continuous envelope of <math>A</math>{{sfn|Akbarov|2016}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2013}};
* for each [[locally compact abelian group]] <math>G</math> the [[Fourier transform]] <math> F_A:C^\star(G)\to C(\widehat{G})</math> is a continuous envelope of the [[Stereotype algebra#Stereotype group algebras|stereotype group algebra]] <math>C^\star(G) </math> of measures with compact support on <math>G</math>{{sfn|Akbarov|2016}}.
In [[abstract harmonic analysis]] the notion of envelope plays a key role in the generalizations of the [[Pontryagin duality]] theory{{sfn|Akbarov|2017}} to the clases of non-commutative groups: the holomorphic, the smooth and the continuous envelopes of [[stereotype algebra]]s (in the examples given above) lead respectively to the constructions of the holomorphic, the smooth and the continuous dualities in ''big geometric disciplines'' – [[complex geometry]], [[differential geometry]], and [[topology]] – for certain classes of (not necessarily commutative) topological groups considered in these disciplines ([[affine algebraic group]]s, and some classes of [[Lie group]]s and Moore groups).{{sfn|Akbarov|2009}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2016}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017}}{{sfn|Kuznetsova|2013}}

== Introduction == In mathematics, '''equivariant topology''' is the study of [[topological space]]s that possess certain symmetries. In studying topological spaces, one often considers continuous maps <math>f:X \to Y</math>, and while equivariant topology also considers such maps, there is the additional constraint that each map "respects symmetry" in both its domain and target space.
The notion of symmetry is usually captured by considering a [[Group action]] of <math>G</math> on <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> and demanding that <math>f</math> is [[Equivariant map|equivariant]] under this action, so that <math>f(g\cdot x)=g \cdot f(x)</math> for all <math>x \in X</math>, a property usually denoted by <math>f:X \to_{G} Y</math> . Heuristically speaking, standard topology views two spaces as equivalent "up to deformation," but equivariant topology considers spaces equivalent up to deformation so long as it pays attention to any symmetry possessed by both spaces. A famous theorem of equivariant topology is the [[Borsuk–Ulam theorem]] , which asserts that every <math>\mathbf{Z}_2</math>-equivariant map <math>f:S^n \to \mathbb R^n</math> necessarily vanishes.
== Induced <math>G</math>-bundles == An important construction used in [[Equivariant cohomology]] and other applications includes a naturally occurring group bundle ( see [[Principal bundle]] for details.)
Let us first consider the case where <math>G</math> acts freely on <math>X</math>. Then, given a <math>G</math>-equivariant map <math>f:X \to_G Y</math>, we obtain sections <math>s_f: X/G \to (X \times Y)/G </math> given by <math>[x] \mapsto [x,f(x)]</math>,
where <math>X \times Y</math> gets the diagonal action, <math>g(x,y)=(gx,gy)</math> and the bundle is <math>p:(X \times Y)/G \to X/G</math>, with fiber <math>Y</math> and projection given by <math>p([x,y])=[x] </math>. Often, the total space is written <math>X \times_G Y</math>
More generally, the assignment <math>s_f</math> actually does not map to <math>(X \times Y)/G</math> generally. Since <math>f</math> is equivariant, if <math>g \in G_x</math>(the isotropy subgroup), then by equivariance, we have that <math>g \cdot f(x)=f(g \cdot x)=f(x)</math>, so in fact <math>f</math> will map to the collection of <math>\{[x,y] \in (X \times Y)/G \mid G_x \subset G_y\}</math>. In this case, one can replace the bundle by a [[Equivariant cohomology#Homotopy quotient|homotopy quotient]] where <math>G</math> acts freely and is bundle homotopic to the induced bundle on <math>X</math> by <math>f</math>.
== Applications To Discrete Geometry == In the same way that one can deduce the [[Ham sandwich theorem]] from the Borsuk-Ulam Theorem, one can find many applications of equivariant topology to problems of discrete geometry.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9783540003625|title=Using the Borsuk-Ulam Theorem - Lectures on Topological Methods in Combinatorics and Geometry {{!}} Jiri Matousek {{!}} Springer|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Handbook-Discrete-Computational-Mathematics-Applications/dp/1584883014|title=Handbook of Discrete and Computational Geometry, Second Edition|date=2004-04-15|publisher=Chapman and Hall/CRC|isbn=9781584883012|editor-last=Goodman|editor-first=Jacob E.|edition= 2nd|location=Boca Raton|language=English|editor-last2=O'Rourke|editor-first2=Joseph}}</ref> This is accomplished by using the Configuration-Space Test-Map paradigm:
Given a geometric problem <math>P</math>, we define the ''configuration space'', <math>X</math>, which parametrizes all associated solutions to the problem (such as points, lines, or arcs.) Additionally, we consider a ''test space'' <math>Z \subset V</math> and a map <math>f:X \to V</math> where <math>p \in X</math> is a solution to a problem if and only if <math>f(p) \in Z</math>. Finally, it is usual to consider natural symmetries in a discrete problem by some group <math>G</math> that acts on <math>X</math> and <math>V</math> so that <math>f</math> is equivariant under these actions. The problem is solved if we can show the nonexistence of an equivariant map <math>f:X \to V\setminus Z</math>.
Obstructions to the existence of such maps are often formulated algebraically from the topological data of <math>X</math> and <math>V\setminus Z</math>.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://people.mpim-bonn.mpg.de/matschke/thesisMatschke.pdf|title=Equivariant topology methods In discrete geometry|last=Matschke|first=Benjamin|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> An archetypal example of such an obstruction can be derived having <math>V</math> a vector space and <math>Z=\{0\}</math>. In this case, a nonvanishing map would also induce a nonvanishing section <math>s_f:x \mapsto [x,f(x)]</math> from the discussion above, so <math>\omega_n(X \times_G Y)</math>, the top [[Stiefel–Whitney class]] would need to vanish.
== Examples == * The identity map <math>i:X \to X</math> will always be equivariant. * If we let <math>\mathbf{Z}_2</math> act antipodally on the unit circle, then <math>z \mapsto z^3</math>is equivariant, since it is an odd function. * Any map <math>h:X \to X/G</math> is equivariant when <math>G</math> acts trivially on the quotient, since <math>f(g\cdot x)=f(x)</math> for all <math>x</math>.
== See also == *[[Equivariant cohomology]] *[[Mackey functor]] *[[Equivariant stable homotopy theory]] *[[G-spectrum]]

{{italic title}} '''''Everything Will Be OK''''' is the title of a hard-cover [[folio format]] book and full-length DVD published in 2005 in Italy. It is primarily a collection of videos, animations and print-specific artworks by artists working in and around the internet and is published by ''[[This is a magazine]]'' <ref>[http://www.thisisamagazine.com This is a magazine]</ref>(about nothing). It is the fourth book from a series of experimental publications by Donnachie, Simionato & Son.<ref>[http://www.donnachie-simionato.com Donnachie, Simionato & Son (Publishers)]</ref>
Adrian Shaughnessy, chief-editor of ''Varoom Magazine'' (UK) said “This is not a book, it is an event. Like [[Helmut Newton]]’s book-with-table, or the repackaging of [[Andy Warhol]]’s [[Interview Magazine|''Interview'']] magazine in a suitcase-with-wheels, ...it is more like a portable multi-media exhibition than a book...Donnachie/Simionato have created a publishing phenomenon.”<ref>[http://www.varoom-mag.com ''Varoom Magazine, Journal for Made Images'', Issue 1, August 2006]</ref>
==DVD== Included with each copy of the book is the DVD of the same title containing original time-based artworks and video. The book also contained a plastic devil's horn ([[corna]]) lucky charm bookmark, a sealed sugar-cube, and a pink latex balloon printed with the words "Everything will be OK".
The DVD contains a number of [[Easter egg (media)#Easter eggs on DVDs|easter eggs]] viewable by moving left twice then pressing play when selecting Augustin Gimel's film title from the index. It also has a hidden sub-titles track which when viewed becomes a second layer of black [[silhouettes]] for the video ''Holes in Between'' by Donnachie/Simionato with original music by the avant-garde band [[Starfuckers]]. An archive of This is a magazine online editions from 2002 to 2004, including the Everything will be OK [[Powerpoint]] episode is accessible from the DVD-ROM section.
==Netart== An associated [[net art]] called EverythingwillbeOK.com<ref>[http://www.everythingwillbeok.com Everything will be ok]</ref> comprising a video-loop of an inflatable stick figure has been maintained since 2004.
==Collections== The Everything will be OK project, including the original video DVD and hard-cover book is part of the KIOSK collection, Christoph Keller's<ref>[http://www.curatingdegreezero.org/c_keller/c_keller.html Christoph Keller]</ref> touring art publications archive, now a permanent collection of the National Art Library in Berlin,<ref>[http://www.smb.museum/kb Kunstbibliothek, Stiftung Preussischer Kulturbesitz]</ref> and has been exhibited at the ICA (USA),<ref>[http://www.icaphila.org/exhibitions/beyondkiosk.php Beyond Kiosk, ICA, Philadelphia, United States (2008)]</ref> the Witte de With Center for Contemporary Art Rotterdam (Rotterdam),<ref>[http://www.wdw.nl/project.php?id=48 Printing Matters, Witte de With, Rotterdam, Netherlands (2005)]</ref> [[Artists Space]] (NY), the [[Emily Carr Institute]] (Vancouver), and [[Mudam]] (Luxembourg), among others.
== Selected exhibitions == * ''Hijacked'', [[Perth Institute of Contemporary Arts]], Perth, Australia (2008) * ''Colophon 2007'', [http://www.colophon2007.com/about_colophon/#colophon2007 Independent Publication Festival], Luxembourg (2007) * ''Holes In Between'', [[Netmage]], Bologna, Italy (2006) * ''Reading Room'', [http://www.senko.dk/ Senko Gallery] by [[Sergei Sviatchenko]], Viborg, Denmark (2005) * ''CMYK - International Trend Magazines Festival'', Barcelona, Spain (2004)
